title: Monday, 6th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

PM11:02am

Some chunky news around

PM11:02am

Saudis

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Off shore leaks

PM11:03am

Guess we should go for the former for our pic for today

PM11:03am

11:03 am
PM11:03am

MbS, as he is known

PM11:03am

Night of the Long Curved Knives

PM11:04am

Always recommend reading David Gardner on middle eastern stuff

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Here he is on MbS

PM11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-a1d2-6786f39ef675

PM11:05am

And one from last month on the jitters over reform

11:05 am
PM11:05am

https://www.ft.com...-9a86-4d5a475ba4c5

PM11:05am

And yes, the oil price is up

PM11:06am

But the move in oil company share prices is muted

11:06 am
BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 517.10, up 0.3 (+0.06%), High: 519.20, Low: 516.20, Volume: 5.00m
PM11:06am

Or non-existent!

PM11:07am

I thought my inbox would be full of Saudi-related grey this morning

11:08 am
BE11:08am

The gist from what I've read is that, while it's all very dramatic, Opec policy probably doesn't change so chill hey.

BE11:09am

As per RBC: "MBS seems strongly committed to
anchoring the OPEC agreement deep into 2018 and moving ahead with the Aramco sale."

BE11:09am

The meat, however, is worth reading.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Much of the media attention has focused on the arrest of Prince Al-Waleed bin Talal given his extensive, high-profile business holdings. However, we think the detention of Prince Mutaib bin Abdullah may have more profound internal political implications. Mutaib was Chief and then
Minister of the Saudi Arabian National Guard (SANG) since 2010 and the post was also held by his father, the late King Abdullah. SANG serves as a praetorian guard for the royal family and would be deployed to clear the streets in the event of a major internal uprising.

BE11:10am

SANG has found itself in the middle of palace politics on prior occasions. In 1964 SANG sided with Faisal against King Saud and helped usher the monarch out of power and ensure an orderly transition. Mutaib was a clear favorite of King Abdullah and he was seen as his preferred choice to be the first of the founder’s grandsons to inherit the throne.

BE11:10am

Abdullah, however, never inserted his son in the succession line and the ascension of King Salman and MBS blocked Mutaib’s path to power. However, in the immediate aftermath of the dramatic June dismissal of Mohammad bin Nayef as Crown Prince both Mutaib and MBS’ uncle Prince Ahmed bin Abdulaziz were cited as prominent royal hold-
outs and centers of princely opposition to the new regime. While MBS’ supporters insist that
Saturday’s move had absolutely nothing to do with staving off a coup and maintain that it
was entirely about eradicating corruption, detaining Mutaib does also seemingly serve a
broader power consolidation agenda. The fact that private airstrips were closed on Saturday
also does suggest that more high-level arrests may be looming.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

We also expect that MBS will soon unveil additional economic initiatives and social reforms
in the days ahead (including perhaps a formal end to the guardianship system). As of late, we
have seen MBS employ a strategy of balancing an iron fist with a velvet glove. In the case of
his foreign policy, the military action in Yemen and the Qatar embargo have been balanced
by a diplomatic and economic charm offensive towards Saudi’s traditional foe – Iraq. In
September, a crackdown on critics occurred alongside a serious effort to remove social
restrictions, such as the ban on female driving. This high stakes balancing act remains fraught

BE11:11am

Anyway, skipping onto the oil side of things ......

BE11:12am

11:12 am
BE11:12am

In terms of oil, there was no talk of returning to market share
in Riyadh last week and $60/bbl Brent provides a more optimal enabling environment for
many of MBS’ key initiatives to remake the economy. Hence, we continue to see Saudi
Arabia actively supporting market management, extending the OPEC cut deep into 2018, and
moving ahead with the planned sale of a stake in Aramco. The bigger question about MBS
and oil seems to be of a more medium-term nature. There were some signs last week that
the young leadership is hedging its bets on oil's actuarial table. The Finance Minister
conceded that Vision 2030 was a response to the recent oil price volatility and the need to
ensure a diversified income stream. Similarly, the much-heralded NEOM megacity is slated to
be powered by solar and clean energy and the PIF is seeking to make substantial investments
in those sectors. Thus, there may be a question mark over the role that conventional fossil
fuels will play in the MBS modernization plan as he is clearly focused on all things disruptive.

PM11:13am

(I suspect a few banks here not wanting to write about a potential client maybe doing the world's biggest IPO, ever.)

BE11:14am

(Well indeed. Trump's "come to us" statement on Aramco was extraordinary over the weekend, though all Trump's statements are in some way extraordinary.)

11:15 am
BE11:15am

One more chart.

BE11:15am

PM11:16am

Cheers

11:16 am
undefined
PM11:16am

Footsie flat Omg smile

PM11:17am

But there are a few statements around

11:16 am
PM11:17am

And the odd dead cat

PM11:17am

Deadcat

Playtech PLC (PTEC:LSE): Last: 802.50, up 32.5 (+4.22%), High: 803.50, Low: 764.50, Volume: 6.99m
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Yeah, UK's typically Monday really.

BE11:18am

That Playtech bounce is largely on the back of UBS calling last week's slump an over-reaction, I think.

BE11:19am

"[T]he current share price implies just 1x EV/EBITDA for unregulated earnings which we believe is overdone."

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Or, y'know, rather more than its proper value of 0x EV/EBITDA. But it's all about opinions I guess.

PM11:20am

hehehe

BE11:20am

Peer valuation klaxon.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

We do not believe 1x EV/EBITDA is consistent with the valuations of peers 888 (10.3x, c30% unregulated), GVC (9.2x, c30% unregulated), Kindred and Betsson (11.8x, 8.4x respectively, both with significant exposure to unregulated markets). We also expect the contribution from regulated markets to increase over time as new markets regulate, which should help to drive a re-rating in the shares. We estimate that a 10ppt increase in the contribution from regulated (we currently estimate 55% of gaming in 2018) would drive a c8% increase in fair value per share.

BE11:21am

I mean, I enjoyed 1999 as much as the next markets reporter, but I'm still not quite ready to once again start seeing websites as cheap because other websites are expensive.

BE11:21am

Back to UBS.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

At end-2016 Playtech had net cash of €80m. Given the strong cash generation, our forecasts imply c€250m of spare cash per year, which if used for M&A we estimate could add c5ppt to revenue growth each year. Management stated that the M&A pipeline remains 'very strong' and that it is in a number of active discussions. We expect any acquisitions to be focused on regulated markets which should further help to drive a re-rating of the shares.

BE11:22am

£10 target on sharply reduced forecasts. As in, 17% off 2018.

BE11:22am

(@wayneJ: you might argue that I was being generous.)

11:22 am
undefined
BE11:23am

Guess we should note some of the US news before getting bogged down in the UK.

BE11:23am

Such as Qualcomm late on Friday.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

$100bn takeovers are probably worth a few pixels.

BE11:24am

So ............. bit of a saga, this one.

BE11:24am

Which we can illustrate with our occasional feature, "Fun with out-of-the-money call options."

11:24 am
BE11:24am

In this case, Qualcomm November 17ths.

BE11:24am

PM11:24am

Oooh

11:24 am
BE11:25am

You'll note, if you squint, some pretty solid demand for the $61 November call beginning October 23.

BE11:25am

Which was rather brave given the price was $52 and $54 during this period.

BE11:25am

As it happens, this was the same week that talk arrived with us about something happening around Qualcomm.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

We wracked our brains about what that something might be, without much luck.

BE11:26am

And we chased a bit. I speculate that other media probably did a bit of chasing as well.

BE11:26am

Which might help explain how Dana Mattioli, the WSJ's lead M&A person, ended up as lead byline on a slightly state-the-obvious story on October 31st about Apple looking to design Qualcomm out of the iPhone.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Dana's not usually a tech-beat reporter. Anyway, QCOM goes from nearly $55 to $51.

BE11:27am

Then, a couple of days later, the story lands about a Broadcom hostile.

BE11:27am

Though Qualcom's price has already pinged back to pre the WSJ story so the mooted $70 is once again a 27% premium.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Not sure what you are suggesting here Bryce

BE11:28am

I'm just providing a tick-tock of events. It's been an interesting fortnight, is all I'm suggesting.

BE11:28am

But let's spin back to whether this combo makes sense.

11:28 am
PM11:29am

Sure

BE11:29am

And it sort of does, but only for hugely antitrust reasons. Quadcom would have control the entire wired/wireless supply chain, from your phone to Vodafone's server.

BE11:29am

Exane puts the combined Quadcom market share at 80% networking, 60% wireless and 14% auto

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Nevertheless ........

BE11:30am

There is limited overlap in products between BRCM/QCOM, except for connectivity, which would not be a deal-breaker if spun off. It would be interesting to see if QCOM would be forced to sell off its lucrative but litigious IP business. It is unlikely Broadcom would welcome the risk of ongoing/future litigation vs Apple and other large OEMs. A deal would likely face intense scrutiny from regulators given that the resultant entity would control most of the wireless/networking value chain.

BE11:30am

And Canaccord ......

11:30 am
BE11:30am

We believe the combination could
create shareholder value through potential accretion, synergies, increased share with
Apple and Samsung; in addition, Broadcom could potentially settle the licensing dispute
with Apple in a more-timely manner than could Qualcomm, given Broadom’s strong
relationship with Apple. Further, we believe Qualcomm and Broadcom are uniquely
positioned for reaccelerating revenue and earnings growth as the market transitions to
5G. We believe Qualcomm is well ahead of its competitors in 5G investment and overall
roadmap and also believe Broadcom’s FBAR filters will grow its strong content share in
5G devices versus 4G. Further, we believe Apple would likely need to work more closely
with a combined Qualcomm and Broadcom given the combined companies unique
technology solutions for the smartphone market, and this potential combination could
adversely impact Intel’s share in future iPhone models and the likelihood of future Apple
foundry relationships.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:31am

This Hock Tan is a serious deal junky

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Broadcom's a roll-up. A spectacularly big one.

PM11:32am

Will be $200bn if he gets away with this

BE11:32am

And everyone seems to think a bump will be necessary. Nomura:

11:32 am
BE11:32am

In our view, $70 per share wouldn’t be sufficient. We estimate at $75 per share or $111 billion valuation, Broadcom would fund the deal with $33bn in stock (122mn shares), new debt of $75bn at a coupon rate of 4% and $3bn of cash. This implies a net debt / EBITDA ratio of 4.6x at deal close (assumed to be CY18 year-end) and 3.4x at the end of CY19. In our analysis, we assume cost synergies of 20% ($1.8bn), of which Broadcom realizes half of the synergies in CY19 and the full amount in CY20. We’ve also contemplated an $80/share transaction price and calculated combined EPS between $23.50-$24.00 in CY19 and $26.00-$26.50 in CY20.

undefined
PM11:34am

So Purple Bricks says everythings on track

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Actually that's all it's saying

PM11:34am

Purplebricks Group plc ('Purplebricks' or 'the Group'), the leading hybrid estate agency, confirms that following the closing of the first half of the financial year, it remains on course to meet the board's expectations for the full year.

The Group's Interim Results will be released on 13th December.

BE11:35am

Rather brief statement. Somewhat lacking in detail such as how many houses they've actually sold. Though we expect that by now.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

As in sold sold. Not sold STC.

PM11:36am

Maybe it's decided the best way to tackle its arrogance problem is to not say anything more than they are required by the rules

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 401.69, up 11.69 (+3.00%), High: 406.25, Low: 390.00, Volume: 678.41k
11:36 am
BE11:36am

Hm. Maybe. Though there's an endless amount of stuff from its fans saying its competition rates are no worse and probably better than the regular competition.

BE11:36am

Which, assuming it's true, makes the company's reluctance to give us specifics even more baffling.

BE11:37am

Are KPIs too much to ask for? Apparently, yes. Anyway, nothing much changes .....

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Here's Citi.

BE11:37am

At FY17 Purplebricks guided for UK revenues of
£80m and Australia revenues of £12m in FY18e. At the time this represented a c.20% increase to consensus estimates on a total revenue basis. Consensus revenue estimates for FY18e are £97m, a c.110% increase year on year.

BE11:38am

We expect minimal changes to consensus given the confirmation of full year expectations. Our Buy rating reflects the long-term upside as Purplebricks revolutionizes the industry across the UK, Australia and the US. With strong traction across both the UK and Australia, we see these markets as de-risked compared to the larger US opportunity.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And Investec.

BE11:38am

H1 forecasts: We forecast 1H sales of £40m (+113%) with £35m from the UK (+94%), and group EBITDA of -£2.7m: UK EBITDA increases to £3.9m (1H17 £0.3m) despite increased marketing investment. We forecast Australia loss at -£2.6m with US -£4m. We forecast 1H adj FD EPS -1.5p (-1.1p).

PM11:38am

Who are still ultra fans, i assume

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Valuation upside: PURP is disrupting the UK market convincingly. Our UK DCF value is c.200p on our base case at 6% market share of transactions by 2022 vs our current estimated 4-5% run rate share, though c. 400p if we assume 9% share – the latter would imply Australia and US in for zero/negative value.

BE11:39am

The only folk I've seen pub this morning are the fans. The brief statement doesn't really give much ammunition for a bear case.

BE11:40am

You'll remember the ASA gave PurpleBricks a small slap last week on making its fee structure clearer.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

As in, tell sellers explicitly that a fee is payable even if the home doesn't sell.

BE11:41am

ASA decided its marketing was misleading and couldn't be broadcast again in current form.

BE11:42am

Though we can't really tell if customers have been led astray by its adverts because .......... we've no bloody idea how many bloody houses it bloody sells!

11:42 am
BE11:43am

W'evs.

undefined
BE11:43am

Should note Sky ........

11:43 am
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 935.00, down 11.5 (-1.22%), High: 951.50, Low: 895.00, Volume: 2.04m
BE11:44am

Live price down 1.8%.

BE11:44am

Ofcom saying Fox News was in breach of broadcasting standards.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

Fell short on "due impartiality" and names Sean Hannity and Tucker Carlson Tonight specifically.

BE11:45am

As in, some Hannity report on the Trump travel ban did not give the viewers “justification to outweigh the numerous highly critical statements made about people who had opposed the order, coupled with the clear support being expressed for the policies of President Trump".

BE11:46am

Tucker Carlson was something on the Manchester bomb that was seen as anti-UK, without considering the counterpoint that actually the UK isn't all that bad really, all considered.

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Fox doesn't do impartiality at all. Never has, never will.

BE11:47am

Different broadcasting standards over there. TV in the US follows the rules that the print tabloids follow here.

BE11:47am

And mostly (though with a couple of exceptions), US newspapers follow the rules that UK broadcaster apply.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

(@Pseudonym: RT's been censured by Ofcom nearly as much as Fox, I think.)

BE11:48am

Anyway, Fox News was pulled from the UK on August 29

BE11:48am

Gave its licence back at the start of this month.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

So, it's debatable whether this has a direct readthrough for the chances of Sky-Fox being blocked. One could argue that the Fox withdrawal has lanced that particular boil, or ......... not.

undefined
BE11:51am

Over in the world of sellside, we have Convatec bouncing.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

And I'm sure the ROTR are thrilled by the prospect of talking about catheters.

ConvaTec Group PLC (CTEC:LSE): Last: 192.30, up 10.3 (+5.66%), High: 196.00, Low: 184.00, Volume: 4.43m
PM11:52am

The bounce has taken a while coming

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Hit a record low on Friday, partly on the back of UBS saying it was trapped in a marketing Cold War with Coloplast.

BE11:53am

We wrote that up for the Saturday reader: https://www.ft.com...-b8a3-38a6e068f464

BE11:53am

And now, as of today, UBS says, "but hang on actually Convatec's cheap".

11:53 am
BE11:54am

The stock is currently pricing in an overly bearish base case scenario in our view. In order to see the stock valued at £1.90 we have to assume the Ostomy division will never return to market growth, that EBIT margins will stabilise at a level 450bps below those delivered in 2016, and that non-Ostomy divisions only grow 4%/ year. Despite the company's execution issues since IPO and recent investments at Coloplast none of these assumptions belong in a base case scenario in our view. After Q3 results we lower our PT 40p to £2.60; leaving ~40% upside to the current price. Buy.

BE11:54am

Near term earnings uncertainty is high, so we have taken a deliberately cautious stance
and assume that the manufacturing issues in Ostomy take until late 2018 to resolve, significantly impairing both revenue growth and profitability. We model a 5% fall in Ostomy sales in Q4 17, the same again throughout 2018, 2017 gross margins below guidance with no sequential improvement in 2018 at all, and an opex/sales ratio 50bps above 2017 guidance with cost inflation ahead of sales until 2019. As a result of this cautious stance our 2018 EPS estimates fall ~20%.

BE11:55am

However our 2020 estimates fall by only ~13%. The 2017 execution issues negate neither the Ostomy turnaround nor the gross margin improvement stories in our view. ConvaTec is still improving the demand for their Ostomy products even if they cannot supply this demand at present, and whilst the benefits of the Margin Improvement Program are delayed, and may cost more to deliver, they are not impaired in our view.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

That's the idea. Even though it's been a complete bust since the float, 15x 2018 is too cheap.

undefined
BE11:56am

Oh, and while on medical devices .....

11:56 am
BE11:56am

(Guess a colostomy bag is more of a medical product than a medical device, but whatever, stay with me here.)

Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,409, down 3 (-0.21%), High: 1,416, Low: 1,399, Volume: 667.02k
BE11:57am

So we mentioned last week about not having clear sight of what Elliot wants S&N to do.

11:57 am
PM11:58am

You did

BE11:58am

And now we do.

BE11:58am

According to sources close to Arash, Elliott has been pushing for S&N to sell the ortho recon unit.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

And I believe there's a meeting set up between Elliott and the S&N chairman Roberto Quarta post results.

BE12:00pm

(Wait, it's still Roberto Quarta right? I should have checked that before typing it.)

PM12:00pm

Any sense of how big the ortho unit is?

12:00 pm
PM12:01pm

(And yes Roberto Quarta is still chairman)

BE12:01pm

Not really, no. And I'm not clear on whether or not it's a poison pill to an ultimate takeover by J&J or whoever.

BE12:01pm

Here's the website: http://www.smith-n...ic-reconstruction/

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Thx

BE12:02pm

My initial impression is that J&J or Stryker whoever would be the likely buyers of that division rather than of the rump .... but I'm not an expert in this sector so that's mostly a guess.

undefined
12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Look at the time

PM12:03pm

I think we are done

PM12:03pm

Thanks for all that Bryce

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

And cheers for joining us on the right

PM12:04pm

I'm off-line for a few days. But Bryce is around -- so do come back tomorrow at 11am sharp.

PM12:04pm

Bye

11:30 am
BE11:30am

While we believe
Qualcomm’s assumptions for the potential outcome for the ongoing royalty disputes will
have a large impact on considering a price to sell the company, we believe the Board
of Directors would likely reject this initial roughly $100B potential offer as too low and
prefer to remain independent.
